name: Bike & Hike Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: All 34 miles of the Bike & Hike trail are paved. Some portions of the trail use neighborhood streets. Please follow the green biking signs until you rejoin the established trail. For your convenience, restrooms are located at the Brandywine Falls, SR 303, Springdale, Silver Springs and SR 91 lots.

name: Bike & Hike Connector
description: Bike & Hike Connector extends the Bike & Hike Trail to connect the northern and southern legs of the Bike & Hike Trail.

name: Overlook Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: The flat, easy Overlook Trail provides spectacular views of the Cuyahoga River, 125 feet below the Overlook Deck. Good for users with wheelchairs, walkers, canes and strollers.

name: Oxbow Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: The moderate Oxbow Trail provides welcome refuge from the everyday hustle and bustle of urban life.

name: Chuckery Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: The trail gives hikers a glimpse of the Indian Signal Tree, reportedly shaped by American Indians, before passing the Cuyahoga River, crossing the parkway and heading uphill; then it loops back to the start.

name: Schumacher Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: The hilly Schumacher Trail provides a closer look at some of Summit County's most pristine scenery.

name: Valley Link Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: The Valley Link Trail connects to the Schumacher Valley Area of Cascade Valley / North.

name: Quarry Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: Discarded mill stones are scattered along the moderate Quarry Trail, which takes visitors through the woods to an old quarry. You can also link to the Towpath Trail and take a short spur to the park's namesake, the deepest lock on the Ohio & Erie Canal.

name: Towpath Connector
description: Deep Lock Quarry Towpath Connector Trail connects to the Towpath Trail.

name: Daffodil Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: An estimated 40,000 daffodils -- including dozens of varieties -- bloom each spring along the H.S. Wagner Daffodil Trail, named for the park district's first director-secretary, who planted the first bulbs here in the late 1930s. Peak bloom is typically mid-April.

name: Old Mill Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: The trail takes hikers through beech-maple woods. Be sure to look for the Brush Family marker, which reads: "To all those who love as he loved the far sky and smiling land."

name: Rock Creek Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: The picturesque Rock Creek Trail leads hikers on a shaded, basic trail through beautiful beech-maple woods.

name: Stream Restoration Trail
description: This trail takes you by the stream restoration project.

name: Redwing Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: Redwing Trail is an easy loop footpath that connects to the Willow Trail.

name: Walking Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: The easy Walking Course is a favorite among seniors and young families. It passes the Tuscarawas Race and connects to Willow Trail.

name: Willow Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: Willow Trail passes the Tuscarawas Race, Tuscarawas River and Little Turtle Pond, where young anglers 15 and under can fish.

name: Freedom Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: The Freedom Trail travels 4.2 miles between the Middlebury Lot to Tallmadge Circle. When completed, this eight-mile multipurpose trail will connect Akron and Kent and become another popular linear park managed by Metro Parks, Serving Summit County.

name: Gorge Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: Gorge Trail provides access to Mary Campbell Cave, an easy half-mile walk from the parking lot. At the start of the trail, a short (half-mile, round trip) section earns Class B status and is good for users with wheelchairs, walkers, canes and strollers. The trail quickly becomes more rugged as it passes through stunning rock-ledge formations. An upper section of the trail is even considered "primitive," earning Class D status.

name: Glens Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: Glens Trail, on the opposite side of Front Street, provides views from the edge of the Cuyahoga River. Springs flow from the ledges along this trail, providing water needed for liverwort.

name: Albermarle Connector Trail
description: Gorge Metro Park connector trail to the neighborhoods to the north and east of the park.

name: Highbridge Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: Highbridge Trail offers a moderately challenging hike on the other side of the Cuyahoga than the Glens and Gorge trails, and it connects to Cascade Valley / South.

name: Connector Trail
description: Gorge Connector Trail offers pedestrian entrance to the park from Front Street.

name: Parcours Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: For a good workout, try this challenging hiking trail with numbered exercise stations.

name: Piney Woods Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: Although this trail is named for the many pines once planted in the park, they are giving way to a variety of other species through natural succession, including black cherries, oaks and tuliptrees.

name: Alder Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: Alder Trail leads through the woods to Alder Pond, where a cattail marsh provides good wildlife habitat. At the start of the trail, a short (half-mile, round trip) section earns Class B status and is good for users with wheelchairs, walkers, canes and strollers.

name: Adam Run Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: One of the park district's most demanding hikes; forms a sort of figure eight with Spring Hollow Trail. Travels through ravines and over streams.

name: Spring Hollow Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: One of the park district's most demanding hikes; forms a sort of figure eight with Adam Run Trail. Travels through ravines and over streams and includes a 30-foot bridge.

name: Sugarbush Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: Sugarbush Trail loops through the city-run recreation area. The distance measured does not include the walk around the ballfield to the trailhead. For more information, please call the city of Twinsburg's Parks & Recreation Department at 330-963-8722.

name: Buttonbush Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: Located in the conservation area, the trail follows an old service road, where vehicles once traveled to and from oil wells, last used in 2003. Today, you'll walk between two large buttonbush swamps. The trail's namesake, the buttonbush, is a flowering shrub that grows in shallow water about one to two feet deep.

name: Ledges Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: Visitors pass by a unique system of sandstone ledges, into Glacier Cave and to a wetland before traveling back to the trailhead over a long boardwalk. The ledges are covered by a "living skin." Ferns, mosses and lichens grow here, and endangered bats and other species live in the area. For the protection of natural resources, please stay on the trail.

name: Liberty Bike Trail
conditions: Accessible and dogs allowed
description: Multi-purpose trail from the naturalist house at the south end of Liberty Park north to the Ledges Area of the park.

name: Prairie Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.

name: Indian Spring Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: Inside the Lake Area, Indian Spring Trail loops through two types of forests and near wetlands, ponds, a stream and the trail's namesake, an old spring.

name: Meadow Loop Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: The short Meadow Loop is a flat, easy trail in the Tallmadge Meadows Area that can be enjoyed by users with wheelchairs, walkers, canes and strollers.

name: Meadow Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: From the parking lot of the Tallmadge Meadows Area, the Meadow Trail passes by the County Home cemetery and travels through woods, a shrub thicket, wetland woods and its namesake meadow. Several boardwalks help visitors traverse the wet areas.

name: Weaver School Connector Trail
description: Connector trail from Tallmadge Meadows Area of Munroe Falls Metro Park to Weaver School.

name: Neighborhood Connector
description: Neighborhood Connector Trail to connect Tallmadge Meadows to neighborhoods west of Darrow Road (SR 91).

name: Nursing Home Connector
description: Nursing Home Connector Trail connects Tallmadge Meadows to the nursing home to the north for visitors.

name: Seneca Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: Seneca Trail is a partly unpaved loop leading visitors past pines, a deciduous forest and through an open prairie. Portions of the trail may be considered strenuous due to hilly terrain.

name: Cherry Lane Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: Cherry Lane Trail is an easy-to-travel loop that connects to Fernwood Trail at a 110-foot-long suspension bridge, taking visitors across a 45-foot-deep ravine.

name: Fernwood Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: Fernwood Trail is an easy-to-travel loop that connects to Cherry Lane Trail at a 110-foot-long suspension bridge, taking visitors across a 45-foot-deep ravine.

name: Deer Run Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: The challenging, and aptly-named, Deer Run Trail follows a path worn by white-tailed deer and provides scenic views of the Cuyahoga River Valley. How many steps do you count on the hike back to the top?

name: Buckeye Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: This statewide trail circles from the Ohio River (near Cincinnati) to Lake Erie (near Mentor), west to Toledo and then back to the Ohio River. Here in Summit County, the trail passes through Deep Lock Quarry, O'Neil Woods, Sand Run and Cuyahoga Valley National Park. "Follow the blue blazes" for the Buckeye Trail.

name: Prairie Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: Though the prairie will take years to fully develop, the easy Prairie Trail leads visitors from the parking lot into what could become a birding hotspot in just a few years.

name: Pheasant Run Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: Pheasant Run Trail winds through fields and woods and around small ponds.

name: Chippewa Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: Along Chippewa Trail, mature trees have grown from thousands of seedlings planted by Girl Scout troops between 1967 and 1983.

name: Bridle Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: The Bridle Trail at Silver Creek is the only horseback trail managed by Metro Parks, Serving Summit County.

name: Jogging Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: The Parkway Jogging Trail is the most popular in the park district, averaging more than 1,000 users a day, year-round. At the start of the trail, from the Old Portage Area, a one-mile (round trip) section earns Class B status and is good for users with wheelchairs, walkers, canes and strollers.

name: Parcours Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: For a good workout, try this challenging hiking trail with numbered exercise stations.

name: Dogwood Trail
conditions: Accessible for most of its length, except for a small section of the loop around Stow Lake
description: Explore shady valley and ridge-top terrain along the wooded and challenging Dogwood Trail.

name: Mingo Trail
conditions: Dogs allowed in the lake area only.
description: The wooded Mingo Trail harbors a variety of wildlife and oak, beech and tulip trees. West of Shady Hollow Pavilion, the trail becomes quite rugged, earning Class D status.

name: Wood Hollow Trail
description: Wood Hollow Trail travels past forests and wetlands.

name: Stanford Trail
description: Stanford Trail at the east end has Brandywine Falls and traveleing west goes by the youth hostel and to the Towpath Trail.
